repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Literacy and Functional Skills Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. The key lessons learned include: 1)
            In a large project, it is important to contract out
            peripheral elements so that the staff of the implementing
            agency can focus on the primary project goals. 2)
            Large-scale projects require high levels of political
            support and commitments as well as strong participation at
            the grassroots level both by the communities and their
            leaders. 3) Strong and stable leadership of the top project
            management is key to providing direction, guidance, and
            support to staff. 4) The project must be designed to be
            flexible and responsive to the needs and perceptions of the
            learners. 5) The project can play an important role in the
            community by incorporating development activities into the
            regular class schedule and involving learners in related
            schemes for improving the local community. 6) For Ghana to
            eradicate illiteracy, the formal and non-formal education
            sectors must ensure that their respective programs are
            cost-effective and of high quality. Also, the implementing
            agency can provide non-governmental providers of literacy
            services with technical assistance and teaching materials.
            7) Literacy instruction is more likely to be effective and
            to sustain participants' motivation when it is clear to
            the learners that being literate will improve their daily
            lives. 8) Literacy interventions need to be continually
            monitored to ensure that they are effective.

repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Literacy and Functional Skills Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will support and consolidate
            the government's program of functional literacy.  The
            project's objectives are to:  (a) assist in
            strengthening the institutional capacity of the Non-Formal
            Education Division (NFED) to manage effectively the entire
            literacy program; (b) ensure that all program aspects are
            subject to frequent evaluation and monitoring, and that
            research and evaluation become key inputs in the development
            of any new initiatives; (c) improve the existing literacy
            program so that a large proportion of the 840,000 adults who
            will be allowed to participate become fully literate; (d)
            ensure that all new literates, whether from the school
            system or from the literacy program have access to a range
            of reading materials in Ghanaian languages; and (e) to help
            expand the coverage of the FM broadcasting system to support
            the functional literacy program and to increase the
            frequency of educational broadcasting in the Ghanaian
            languages.  The project's main objective is to improve
            the quality of life of the poorest Ghanaians, especially
            those in the rural areas.  Credit funds will be used to
            finance the production of printed materials; procurement of
            radios, bicycles, and sewing machines as incentives for
            facilitators and supervisors; procurement of development
            inputs, vehicles and office furniture and equipment; staff
            training and technical assistance; and the construction of
            office and storage facilities.
